urn:contentItem:7VXG-YDC1-2RYX-1017-00000-00fast facts2009-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisFACTOR XPg. 6fast facts

1. Walt Disney designed a character while on a train to Los Angeles.

He showed it to his wife and said his name was Mortimer Mouse. The wife did not like the name and suggested Mickey Mouse. And so was the birth of Mickey Mouse.

2. Donald Duck's full name is Donald Fauntleroy Duck.

3. Pluto was not always Mickey's pet dog. He first appeared in The Chain Gang as a bloodhound sent to look for Mickey, who had escaped from prison.

4. Who has the biggest nose of all the dwarfs in Snow White? Grumpy!

5. Some of the scenes in Bambi (woodland creatures and the forest fire) are unused footage from Pinocchio.

FACT OR FICTION:

Walt Disney holds the record for the most Oscars.

He has won 220.

FICTION:

Walt Disney holds the record with 22 Oscars.

It was started by an improperly extinguished barbecue, officials said, and was fanned by strong winds.</p><p>Firefighters were cutting breaks to contain the fire.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:57FX-YJX1-JD34-V3BT-00000-00The right tools for the biggest job2013-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 6The right tools for the biggest jobBUSHFIRE EMERGENCYIlya Gridneff

THE uniforms may have changed but the fire threat remains the same.

In days gone by, gum tree branches and overalls were the only line of defence for a raging bushfire. These days, volunteer firefighters are equipped with the best personal protection equipment on offer.

Lithgow Rural Fire Service volunteers Josh Murray, 23, and Ash Mansell, 23, explained that from their Taipan fire boots - oil and chemical resistant, with high ankle support for rough terrain - to their fire helmets, made from the toughest grade of Kevlar and hard plastic, they are ready for any inferno.

Proban chemical compound fire retardant undershirts, pants, leather gloves and similarly treated bright orange wildfire jackets with reflectors are standard issue now for RFS volunteers.

As they fight fires in their 4x4 Village Pumper-Hino Chassis truck, with a 3000 litre galvanised steel water tank, they are also tuned into standard radio, free-to-air VHF for local air base, RFS private mobile radio and truck-to-truck VHF fire ground communication.

Helicopters provide water bombing and all their logistics are co-ordinated via cutting-edge technology at the RFS headquarters in Lidcombe, in Sydney's west.

TWO PHOTOS: Ready to go to work ... Josh Murray and Ash Mansell, both volunteers for the Lithgow Rural Fire Service, in their work gear. Photo: Mick Tsikas Back in 1939 ... firefighters battling a forest fire with improvised beaters. Photo: Fairfax Photo Archive

urn:contentItem:7VBN-0DV1-2RG7-24NG-00000-00Crews continue to battle two large bushfires2009-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisCrews continue to battle two large bushfires

Fire crews are fighting a 1000-hectare blaze in the state's south west.

The forest fire is about 20 kilometres south east of Nelson.

About 100 firefighters, two planes and two helicopters are trying to contain the blaze.

DSE spokesman Rob Price says the fire is pushing north-west towards a large pine plantation.

"There are currently no threats to residence or communities, but we have resources from both DSE, CFA and pine plantation people at the fire," he said.

"We also have aircraft support and we've got a number of other taskforces going to that fire."

Meanwhile, firefighters have built a containment line around a bushfire near Bright in the state's north east.

The fire is believed to have started from an unattended campfire, 13 kilometres north of Bright.

It has burnt 100 hectares of state forest and is not threatening people or property.

urn:contentItem:49NY-M1N0-01S8-D361-00000-00<published>1995-07-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:03:47Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>HUGE FIRE A BIBLICAL DISASTER, SAYS PM</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PARIS C</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A HUGE forest fire which raged through the outskirts of Athens for the past three days, gutting homes and destroying woodland, was brought under control yesterday, the fire brigade said."The blaze is under partial control but many units remain in the area to make sure the wind does not fan any new fronts," a fire department spokesman said.</p><p>"We believe we will fully control it very soon."Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou described the outbreak, the worst for 50 years, as "a biblical catastrophe".The blaze started near Mt Pendeli, overlooking Athens, which is dotted with luxurious villas, summer homes and children's summer camps.Thousands of people were evacuated from houses, hospitals and camps and police reported 20 people injured.As gale winds eased, Greek, French and Italian planes bombarded the blaze with tonnes of water. Five helicopters from Germany were due to join the fight later in the day after the Government asked for urgent help from European Union partners.The region north-east of the city has been declared a disaster area.At the same time, forest fires ravaged Spain and a heatwave in Italy caused at least five deaths.- REUTEREND OF urn:contentItem:4TJT-HT40-TXDB-G071-00000-00Pilot killed in Darling Downs cropduster crash2008-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisPilot killed in Darling Downs cropduster crash

A man has been killed in a cropduster crash on the Darling Downs, in south-east Queensland.

The plane came down north of Warwick shortly after 2:30pm AEST.

Fire crews are battling to contain a blaze sparked by the accident.

Emergency Services spokeswoman Michelle Fowler says the plane is still on fire.

"We've got three crews on scene at the moment," she said.

"One crew is trying to put out the fire at the plane and the other two are dealing with the grass fire.

"We have got very dry and windy conditions in the south-east region at the moment and they are expected to continue for the rest of the afternoon.

"[There are] very extreme forest fire dangers so we will be keeping a close eye on that."

urn:contentItem:4P3F-1010-TX5J-G30K-00000-00Greek fire rages as heat toll lifts2007-07-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisFOREIGNPg. 36Greek fire rages as heat toll lifts

HUNDREDS of firefighters and troops battled a forest fire on a mountain overlooking Athens as Greece's longest heatwave on record claimed three new victims.

A cloud of smoke blocked the sun over the Greek capital and ash rained as 200 firefighters, 300 troops, and 12 planes carrying water, battled four fire-fronts on Mt Parnitha.

The heatwave that has seared the country and much of southern Europe since mid-June has killed 12 people in Greece and about 50 in other countries.

The government said it had ''successfully handled a difficult task'', but it came under heavy criticism for failing to adequately protect one of the few green areas around the heavily polluted Greek capital.

urn:contentItem:7WK0-9190-Y9B7-54H3-00000-00Vic: Firefighters back from helping in Canada2009-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Firefighters back from helping in CanadaMELBOURNE Sept 8

  Australian and New Zealand firefighters have returned home from battling blazes in Canada to take a break before they gear up for the local bushfire season.


   The 33 firefighters worked in the Kamloops area, approximately 350km east of Vancouver, serving as air operations managers, fire behaviour analysts, field supervisors and managers of large base camps.
   "The hard-working group of men and women from all around Australia and New Zealand will now have a well-earned rest before getting back to preparation works for our own fast-approaching bushfire season," said Ewan Waller, chairman of the Australia-NZ forest fire management group.
    "They were strongly and warmly welcomed by the community and Canadian fire authorities and everyone has gained much experience to bring home," Mr Waller said.
   Firefighters from British Columbia helped Victoria in the 2006/07 Great Divide Fire and after the Black Saturday fires in February this year.
   "This recent deployment to Canada was our turn to help them through what was a very difficult summer," Mr Waller said.

urn:contentItem:545T-HS71-F0N8-R248-00000-00FORESTS NSW firefighters take their fitness2011-09-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 4FORESTS NSW firefighters take their fitnessLauren Green

FORESTS NSW firefighters take their fitness very seriously. To ensure the safety of personnel before the fire season starts, Forests NSW conduct an annual fitness assessment to determine if staff are physically up to the challenge of working on the front line of a forest fire. Assessment coordinator Mark Drury said there are three levels of assessment used to determine what each fire fighter can do on the fire line. Each level involves the carrying of an 11.3 kilogram pack for a certain distance within a specified period of time. "What we call the arduous level involves walking 4.8 kilometres in under 45 minutes; the moderate level is 3.2 kilometres in under 30 minutes; and the lower level is 1.6 kilometres in under 16 minutes. "All our firefighters train in preparation for the assessment and maintain their fitness throughout the fire season," Mark said. Fighting fires within the vast forested landscapes of NSW State Forests can be extremely risky, therefore the annual fitness assessment was implemented in 2003 to ensure firefighters remain in the best possible shape, for their own safety and for the safety of the community.

Forest NSW fire fighters: Alan Eagan, Tony Drummond, Andrew Goodman, Ryan Pellew, Dave Power and Greg Fahey.

urn:contentItem:53HW-1YR1-JCM0-64XJ-00000-00Firefighters quell Tablelands blaze2011-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisFirefighters quell Tablelands blazeKirsty Nancarrow and Abigail Stanbridge

The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) says it is continuing to be kept busy with fires on the Tablelands in the state's far north.

Fire authorities spent several hours last night trying to contain a fire that burnt our 20 acres of cane farm and grassland at Chewko, south-west of Mareeba.

The QFRS says six tankers and a rural fire brigade crew took more than three hours to bring the blaze under control.

Superintendent Alan Hogg says a car was destroyed and large irrigator was under threat during the blaze.

"We kept it away from property and that's a great thing," he said.

"But as the season progresses and it gets hotter and drier and the winds pick up, it gets more difficult.

"The quicker we can prepare and be ready, the safer the community will be."

Meanwhile, firefighters yesterday managed to contain a large grassfire which has been threatening homes near Mareeba for two days.

Crews are still stationed near Hastie and Hoolihan roads to monitor the situation.

Authorities say a large forest fire is also burning in State Forest three kilometres from Ravenshoe on the Southern Tablelands.

That fire is in inaccessible forest and at this stage it is not threatening any properties.

urn:contentItem:4MYW-GDX0-TX5J-F2WN-00000-00Swelter invites bushfire repeats2007-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Swelter invites bushfire repeats

FIREFIGHTERS are back on high alert with temperatures predicted to hit 40C across the state today.

The fire danger is expected to be extreme in the forested areas of the Mallee, Wimmera and the state's central north and northeast.

The CFA advised people living in areas at risk to activate their bush fire plans.

A Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman warned there was the potential for extreme fire danger today and tomorrow.

''The amount of rain in the last two weeks is not enough to alleviate the potential forest fire danger,'' he said.

Although most fires have been contained, firefighters were still battling a blaze in Gippsland, 20km southwest of Cobungra, where the fire continued to burn near the Dargo River.

urn:contentItem:4T49-CNB0-TX5N-000F-00000-00Fire devastates Rhodes2008-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisPg. 6Fire devastates Rhodes

MORE than 500 firefighters, 100 soldiers and 16 aircraft -- including four water bombers from Italy and France and a helicopter from Cyprus -- were sent to Rhodes to control a forest fire that raged for six days.

The fire is believed to have destroyed more than 5000ha of forest and brush on the island, one of Greece's prime travel destinations. It also threatened a village and led to three hotel evacuations.

``The fire stole a march on us on the first day because the water-bombing planes were grounded for hours due to thick smoke,'' a spokesman said. ``If we had helicopters at that stage, we would have contained it.''

A 61-year-old man has been sentenced to four years' jail and fined $A24,750 for starting the fire by negligence.

Risk of fire in Greece is particularly high this summer because of low rainfall and strong winds.

Last year, devastating forest fires killed 77 people.

urn:contentItem:4S74-2S80-TX5N-005G-00000-00On this day2008-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 74On this day

25 YEARS AGO:

* Tasmania's dam battle lines have been drawn with the Federal Government filing a writ in the High Court seeking to halt work on the Gordon-below-Franklin dam. The Tasmanian Government has countered with a writ claiming the Commonwealth action is invalid.

* Adelaide recorded its highest March rainfall in 98 years. The 106mm drenching was 400 per cent above the March average.

50 YEARS AGO:

* Eight men have been burned to death in SA's worst forest fire tragedy. The men were trapped in three fire trucks by a fire which raged for 17 hours in a State pine forest near Mt Gambier.

* The road toll for the first three days of the Easter long weekend stands at 26, with 10 deaths on NSW roads. Victoria has recorded 7 deaths, SA 5 and Queensland and WA each 2.

urn:contentItem:4VFC-RGX0-TXX1-F01M-00000-00Arsonist faces five kill counts2009-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 45Arsonist faces five kill counts

RIVERSIDE, California: A serial arsonist started a California forest fire that left five firefighters dead in a plot to stop his pit bull terrier from being euthanised, a court heard yesterday.

Prosecutors in Riverside, 90km east of Los Angeles, said Raymond Lee Oyler was a man ``bent on destruction'' who had started the October 2006 fire out of anger that his dog had been impounded.

Oyler, 38, is on five charges of murder and 40 arson-related counts and faces the death penalty if convicted.

More than 50 houses and buildings were destroyed in the fire.

The firefighters killed were attempting to save people who had not been evacuated when their truck was overrun by flames.

Prosecutor Michael Hestrin said he would use statements from Oyler's girlfriend that he confessed to setting fires and wanted to set a hill ablaze as a distraction so he could rescue his quarantined pit bull terrier that was to be euthanised.

urn:contentItem:4MY1-P2J0-TX52-J318-00000-00LETTER OF THE DAY2007-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 19LETTER OF THE DAY

THE reported 60m-wide firebreak along the northern boundary of the Thomas River catchment indicates the sort of Maginot Line thinking that was proposed more than 50 years ago and rejected as not very sensible.

The draught generated by the tremendous heat of a high-intensity forest fire throws burning debris high into the air to be caught by the wind and dropped, sometimes many kilometres, ahead of the main front.

Also, fires caused by lightning and fires lit accidentally or deliberately occur indiscriminately.

Many things need to be done for effective protection of forests, but bulldozing costly 60m-wide firebreaks is not one of them.

A. Threader, Balwyn

Our letter of the day winner receives a stylish Parker Sonnet fountain pen, courtesy of Parker.

urn:contentItem:4K06-XDF0-TXDB-G1RG-00000-00Fuel reduction burns under fire2005-11-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burns under fire

A former Victorian chief fire officer is criticising the State Government's fuel reduction burn program.

The chairman of Forest Fire Victorian, Athol Hogdson, says the Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) misses opportunities to light prescribed burns because its criteria for conducting them is too tight.

The department has completed a third of its planned burns for this spring.

Mr Hodgson says DSE firefighters could complete more burns if they received better training.

"It's not hard at all, the skills are well known and if the department recognises that fire management is a core business and supports its staff in gaining those skills, it happens quite easily," he said.

urn:contentItem:4V41-DTP0-TXX1-F060-00000-00Smokescreen on burning issue2008-12-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 47Smokescreen on burning issueAthol Hodgson

THE Brumby Government's pledge to triple the number of controlled burns is a smokescreen.

Fine print in the Government's response to the parliamentary environment and natural resources committee report gives it wriggle room to achieve little, but look good. It exposes an intent to move away from large-scale mosaic burns in remote areas, pending further research, while getting kudos from smaller burns around settlements, relying on the feel-good factor to justify its stance.

The same strategy was recommended by the panel conducting the inquiry into the 2002-03 fires. It failed in 2005, 2006 and 2006-07 after the Bracks Government failed to face facts.

The ENR committee got it right. By failing to accept its recommendation, the Brumby Government has consigned another million-plus hectares of forests and park to feral fires. Ash and mudslides will choke watercourses and millions of birds and mammals will die.

The only beneficiaries will be contractors cleaning up the mess.

Athol Hodgson is president, Forest Fire Victoria

The fire broke out on Saturday in a nature reserve in the Guadalajara area east of Madrid after visitors failed to put out a barbecue.</p><p>It then spread out of control.</p><p>Parched by a heatwave and the worst drought since the 1940s, much of Spain is like a tinderbox.</p><p>Riba de Saelices Mayor Jose Luis Samper said a fire patrol from Soria province was surprised by the flames and trapped in a remote spot.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier More than 100 firefighters were battling the blaze.</p><p>Five people were rescued by helicopter after they became trapped in a forest fire in Dorset, southern England.</p><p>Britain hasn't had significant rainfall in 15 days, which is unusual.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4N7G-8XS0-TXDB-G2KS-00000-00King Island fire efforts hampered by underground fuel: TFS2007-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisKing Island fire efforts hampered by underground fuel: TFS

Tasmanian fire crews fighting a major blaze on King Island say it is proving hard to control because it is also burning underground.

The Tasmania Fire Service (TFS) says it has burnt more than 11,000 hectares in three weeks from near Narracoopa in the east to the Martha-Lavinia Reserve in the north.

Incident controller Gavin Freeman says without rain it will keep burning for weeks.

He says the blaze is being fuelled by underground peat deposits.

"[With] a dry forest fire you just [have] the fuels on top of the ground and you can put it out fairly easily just with a bit of water, but with this peat stuff you've actually gotta dig it out and really drown it with water to make sure it's completely extinguished," he said.

urn:contentItem:4K06-KYF0-TXDB-H233-00000-00Piliga fire efforts wind down2005-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisPiliga fire efforts wind down

Fire fighting operations are winding down at the scene of the Piliga Forest fire that has burned out almost 6,000 hectares, near Narrabri in north-east of New South Wales.

The blaze began in the Bibblewindi State Forest, east of Bohena Creek, on Christmas Eve.

Staff from State Forests and the National Parks And Wildlife Service, as well as 150 Rural Fire Service (RFS) volunteers, turned out to control the fire.

Six aircraft were used to water bomb the blaze, which had a perimeter of more than 50 kilometres.

RFS spokesman Shaun Chipman says there were fears the savage weather conditions could have sparked a repeat of the massive bushfire that burned out hundreds of thousands of hectares of the Piliga Forest in the 1990s.

urn:contentItem:7VVC-0ST0-YB64-43VJ-00000-00'Clearer' warnings needed2009-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12'Clearer' warnings neededFIRES ROYAL COMMISSIONDEWI COOKE

A KINGLAKE man whose house was destroyed on Black Saturday has told the Bushfires Royal Commission that the mountain community was almost "immune" to warnings of extreme fire danger.

Dr Chris Harvey and his family lived on Bald Spur Road in Kinglake for 23 years. At least 15 people died on the road.

Dr Harvey said that his dead friends "needed more" than the warnings that were given in the lead-up to February 7. "Today is a day of total fire ban . . . We've listened to this warning ever since we came to Australia," he said.

Dr Harvey said knowing the forest fire danger index for the day, a figure used by fire services to determine how extreme the fire risk is, would help people to better understand. "The CFA and DSE are in the public domain. Information which they have has to be given to us," he said.

Dr Harvey said there had been no fuel reduction clearing since 1962. He blamed the build-up of fuel, the heatwave and drought-like conditions for the fire's severity. --DEWI COOKE

urn:contentItem:4SRD-WJB0-TX5N-0001-00000-00Start your day with a laugh2008-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisJOKESPg. 39Start your day with a laugh

* A PHOTOGRAPHER for a national magazine was assigned to get photos of a great forest fire.

Smoke at the scene was too thick to get any good shots, so he frantically called his home office to hire a plane.

``It will be waiting for you at the airport,'' he was assured by his editor.

As soon as he got to the small, rural airport, sure enough, a plane was warming up near the runway.

He jumped in with his equipment and yelled, ``Let's go! Let's go!''

The pilot swung the plane into the wind and soon they were in the air.

``Fly over the north side of the fire,'' said the photographer, ``and make three or four low level passes.''

``Why?'' asked the pilot.

``Because I'm going to take pictures! I'm a photographer, and photographers take pictures!'' said the photographer with

great exasperation.

After a long pause the pilot said, ``You mean you're not the instructor?''

urn:contentItem:4KY3-MTJ0-TX5P-02N6-00000-00Early fires a danger sign: CFA2006-09-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. S05Early fires a danger sign: CFA

HOT conditions fanned by northerly winds fuelled several fires across the region on Tuesday.

The CFA warned the fire danger period could start as early as October unless spring rain reduced the risk.

Fire crews attended blazes at Freshwater Creek, Drysdale, Apollo Bay and a 40ha forest fire near Barwon Downs in the Otways.

A cool change and light rain dampened the fires but DSE crews were still mopping up the Barwon Downs fire yesterday.

CFA region chief Bob Barry said homeowners should start clearing their properties now, warning the official fire danger period could start six to eight weeks ahead of the usual pre-Christmas timeline.

He said long-range weather forecasts of below-average rainfall and the predicted impact of the el nino drought-inducing weather pattern were danger signs.

urn:contentItem:4K46-7J10-TXDB-G1YS-00000-00Japan's Mt Asama erupts again2004-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisJapan's Mt Asama erupts again

A Japanese volcano that burst into life earlier this month with its biggest eruption in 21 years has erupted again, following several minor eruptions a day earlier.

Japan's Meteorological Agency says two eruptions have been observed from the 2.5 kilometre Mount Asama, about 150 kilometres north-west of the capital.

The agency says smoke billowed about 400 metres high in the first eruption, but it did not observe any ash falling.

The second eruption sent a small amount of ash to surrounding areas.

An eruption on September 1 threw rocks over a wide area and caused a forest fire on the volcano's slopes.

It is the most violent since April 1983.

urn:contentItem:4R5D-X9J0-TXDB-G19C-00000-00Cigarette butt suspected of starting fire2007-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisCigarette butt suspected of starting fire

A forest fire in the state's north east is still burning out of control.

The fire is on Forestry Tasmania land on both sides of the Tasman Highway near Scottsdale.

Forestry's District Manager, Peter Bird, says it is burning in a dry eucalypt forest.

"We've got three bulldozers and two helicopters helping with the control of the fire," he said.

"It's not contained as yet but we're working on that."

Mr Bird says the origins of the fire are not clear.

"We're not exactly sure, but we believe it may have been someone discarded a cigarette butt out the window of their vehicle," he said.

"So if I could ask people to be particularly careful with cigarettes as they're driving along."

There's another bushfire burning near Maydena in the state's South West Conservation Area.

It is believed the fire burning in button grass moorland north of the Adamsfield Track sparked from a lightning strike.

Then she tried to cover up her involvement.</p><p> Barton was charged with setting fire to timber in the national forest, damaging federal property in excess of $175,800 and making false statements.</p><p> Barton was warning campers about the dangers of accidentally setting off a forest fire.</p><p> Brush and wildfires were also burning yesterday in the drought-stricken west, including California.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4PKV-WBS0-TWT9-203N-00000-00Fed:Donations to Greek fire victims tax deductible: Costello2007-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFed:Donations to Greek fire victims tax deductible: CostelloCANBERRA Sept 6

  Donations made to the Greek forest fire disaster will be tax deductible, federal Treasurer Peter Costello said today.
   Mr Costello said public funds established and run by a public benevolent institution that provides money solely for the relief of people in Greece left in distress by the fires could be set up as "developed country relief funds".


   Donations to such funds will tax deductible for a period of two years from August 24.
   The recent fires in Greece have killed more than 60 people and destroyed more than 500 homes, leaving thousands homeless.
   "Australians are all too familiar with the damage and destruction such fires can cause," Mr Costello said in a statement.
   "As the affected communities begin to rebuild, many Australians will wish to contribute donations to assist them at this difficult time."
   Mr Costello's decision comes on top of the $3 million in assistance announced by Prime Minister John Howard on August 27, and the contribution of Australian experts to help firefighting operations.

urn:contentItem:4T2R-4HG0-TX5N-019V-00000-00NEWS IN BRIEF2008-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:03:47ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 21NEWS IN BRIEF

US `faith' in torture

THE US Justice Department told the CIA in a 2002 memo that its interrogators would be safe from prosecution for violations of anti-torture laws if they believed ``in good faith'' that harsh techniques used to break prisoners would not cause ``prolonged mental harm''. The memo was released yesterday.

Ex-army chief jailed

A COURT yesterday sentenced one of Argentina's most feared former military leaders -- Commnader Luciano Benjamin Menendez, 81 -- to life in jail for the 1977 kidnapping, torture and killing of four leftist activists.

Bear attacks woman

A GRIZZLY bear grabbed a US woman's head in its jaws before it was scared away from near a lodge at Cooper Landing, Alaska. Abby Sisk, 21, was in a critical condition yesterday.

FIre rages on Rhodes

FRANCE, Italy and Cyprus yesterday sent firefighting aircraft to help battle a massive forest fire raging for the fourth day on the Aegean island of Rhodes.

Shooting at college

A MAN shot three people yesterday in a community college computer room in Phoenix, Arizona, injuring two critically. A suspect was arrested nearby.

urn:contentItem:4G5R-BJJ0-015H-53YW-00000-00<published>2005-05-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:03:47Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Judy celebrates twentieth</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">EVERYONE seems to be having a significant birthday lately. The latest one to attempt to blow out a forest fire of candles is Judy Ferber (right), who last year won the Order of the Gold Coast.</p><p>To put it as delicately as possible, the Tropicarnival and Gold Coast Eisteddfod stalwart celebrated the 20th anniversary of her 40th birthday this week. Friends and family travelled from all over and met up at Kampung Malay restaurant where Judy's daughters Kate and Lucy led a chorus of congrats and showed a video of the highlights of what has been an eventful life.</p><p>Best line of the night was from granddaughter Chloe, who thanked her grandmother for teaching her about good manners, cooking and backgammon. Trust Judy to focus on life's essentials.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49FD-YT30-015G-W2M5-00000-00<published>2003-08-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:03:47Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 12</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Nice one</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">An Austrian firefighter was pulled 500m into the air after trapping his hand in a water tank on a helicopter.</p><p>Werner Seidl was fighting a forest fire in Greith with 30 other firemen when the accident happened. He was trying to manoeuvre the 600-litre water tank hanging from a low-flying helicopter into place. "The air pressure from the rotor blades pushed me against the tank," he said. "And just as I stretched out my hands to push myself from it, the pilot closed the automatic tank lock and four of my right-hand fingers got stuck in it." The helicopter took off and Seidl was left hanging by his fingers.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
